conversation.content: [hesitantly] So you're here to learn the tango for someone special, your intake form says. [pause] That's quite a romantic gesture, not many people commit to learning something this complex just to impress a partner.

[excited] Yes, it's for my boyfriend Marcus! [cheerfully] He mentioned once that his ex was this incredible dancer and they used to tango together all the time, so I thought maybe if I learned, we could share that too.

[very quietly] Marcus Chen? [clearing throat] I mean, that's a lovely thought, really sweet of you to want to connect with him through dance, though tango is particularly intimate, requires a lot of trust between partners.
[curious] You know him? [surprised] Wait, of course you probably do, this is the only serious dance studio in the neighborhood and he said his ex taught here or something like that.

[bitter] Right, his ex taught here. [slowly] Actually still teaches here every Tuesday and Thursday, which I'm guessing is why you booked Monday lessons, though you probably didn't know that when you signed up.
[confused] How would you know when his ex teaches? [hesitantly] Marcus just said to avoid those days because it might be awkward, but he didn't give me specifics about who or why exactly.

[sarcastically] Because I make the teaching schedule. [sighs] Look, let's just focus on the basics today, starting with your posture and frame, since tango requires a very specific kind of connection between partners.
[anxious] Oh god, you're friends with them, aren't you? [quickly] I'm sorry if this is weird, I had no idea, Marcus just said this was the best studio and I really want to surprise him.

[regretful] The Argentine tango isn't just about the steps, it's about understanding your partner's breath, their weight shifts, the unspoken conversation happening between your bodies. [pause] Marcus used to say it was like having a three-minute love affair.

[friendly] That's exactly how he described it to me! [warmly] He gets this look in his eyes when he talks about dancing, like he's remembering something beautiful but painful at the same time, you know?

[very melancholic] Yeah, I know that look. [quietly] He used to get it when we'd practice our routine for competitions, right before we'd step onto the floor, like he was already mourning the moment ending.
[shocked] Wait, we? [stuttering] You're, oh my god, you're Alex? The Alex who choreographed that piece he has framed in his apartment, the one from the nationals?

[firmly] I'm your instructor, that's all that matters right now. [clearing throat] If you want to learn tango, I'll teach you tango, but we should probably establish some professional boundaries going forward.
[apologetic] I had no idea, I swear, the booking system just showed 'A. Rivera' and I never put it together. [shaky voice] God, this must be so awful for you, teaching me to dance for him.
[warmly] It's actually not awful, it's just strange. [sighs] Seeing someone else want to learn his language, trying to speak to him in the way we used to communicate without words.
[very meekly] Should I leave? [hesitantly] Find another studio? I don't want to make this harder for you than it already is, and Marcus doesn't even know I'm doing this yet.
[confident] No, stay.
[frustrated] How can you be so calm about this? [loudly] I'm literally here learning your dance, your connection with him, trying to recreate something you two had together!

Because dance isn't something you can steal or recreate, it's born from the specific chemistry between two people. [very sincerely] What you'll create with him will be entirely yours, even if you're dancing the same steps we once did.
[relieved] Thank you for saying that. [slowly] I guess I should tell him I'm taking lessons here, shouldn't I? He'll find out eventually, and it's better if it comes from me.
